chapter.title: Basic Concepts and Work Styles
chapter.para: These best practices should be known by every OBS user. They describe how to setup projects, working with own or foreign sources.

section.title: Setup a project re-using other projects binaries
Setup a project reusing other projects sources
section.para: You can also setup your own project using the sources, spec files and patches from another project and develop within this project. #osc copypac SOURCEPRJ SOURCEPAC DESTPRJ By default, &obs; will strip the maintainer info and now make it part of your own project. To clarify, when we speak of a project, it can mean just one package or a complete set of packages with their own build dependencies.

section.title: Contribute Directly to External Projects
section.para: In case a user does not have commit permissions to a project, he can request maintainership permissions for this project. This makes sense if the user is already known to the project owners and they trust him as a maintainer. There is a way to do this via the request system of OBS, but only via osc so far: # osc createrequest -a add_me maintainer PROJECT

section.title: Contribute Indirectly to Foreign Projects
section.para: Users who are new to a given project, either because they are new users with &obs; or packaging or don't have any deeper knowledge about a certain project won't have direct commit permissions. However, they can still create a copy of any package source and ask back to merge their changes. &obs; has support to make this easy.
